snippet.title: Amber Heard confirms role in 'Aquaman 2,' criticizes 'paid campaigns' to remove her from sequel
snippet.description: It's official. Amber Heard will be returning to "Aquaman 2."On Thursday, Heard confirmed to Entertainment Weekly that she would be reprising her role as Mera in the Warner Bros. sequel to the 2018 superhero film."I'm super excited about the amount of fan love and the amount of fan appreciation that 'Aquaman' has acquired and that it has garnered so much excitement for 'Aquaman' and Mera that it means we'll be coming back," Heard said. "I'm so excited to film that."Some on social media speculated whether Heard would return to "Aquaman 2," after a viral Change.org petition titled "Remove Amber Heard from Aquaman 2" called for Warner Bros. and DC Entertainment to "remove Heard from their 'Aquaman 2' film project." As of Friday, the petition received over 1 million signatures.The outcry came after Warner Bros. requested Johnny Depp resign from his role in the "Fantastic Beasts" franchise, which he announced on Nov. 6. His exit from the fantasy film came days after he lost his lengthy libel case against the British tabloid The Sun, who branded Depp a "wife beater" while reporting on his marriage with Heard.Johnny Depp exits 'Fantastic Beasts' franchiseJason Momoa reveals he was 'completely in debt' after 'Game of Thrones'The "Pirates of the Caribbean" actor has maintained his innocence and intends to appeal, and Heard explained the upheaval has not cost her her role. "Paid rumors and paid campaigns on social media don't dictate [casting decisions] because they have no basis in reality," Heard added. "Only the fans actually made 'Aquaman' and 'Aquaman 2' happen. I'm excited to get started next year."A U.K. judge ruled last week the 2018 article in The Sun was not libelous after a contentious legal showdown this summer. In 2018, Depp sued The Sun’s publisher, News Group Newspapers. He strongly denied all of Heard's allegations, countering that she was the abuser in their relationship. Their marriage, Depp told Heard several times, was "a crime scene waiting to happen," he testified.Judge Andrew Nicol delivered his verdict in writing without a hearing – due to the coronavirus – at the High Court in London, dismissing Depp's complaint against The Sun and finding that "the great majority" of Amber Heard's claims of assault could be "proved to the civil standard." A lawyer for Depp, 57, described the decision as “perverse as it is bewildering.”“The judgment is so flawed that it would be ridiculous for Mr. Depp not to appeal this decision,” Jenny Afia said in a statement to USA TODAY.An attorney for Heard, meanwhile, said the verdict was “not a surprise” for anyone who followed the trial.The Sun called the decision a “stunning victory for press freedom” and said that it had stood up and campaigned for victims of domestic abuse for more than 20 years.loses libel case against British tabloid that branded him a 'wife beater' to Amber HeardContributing: Maria Puente
